thread.title: NIDA graduates take a bow in their final student productions
thread.title_full: NIDA graduates take a bow in their final student productions

author: Juliana Yu
title: NIDA graduates take a bow in their final student productions
text:
Third year NIDA students Maree Cole (left) and Miranda Daughtry 
For the National Institute of Dramatic Art's class of 2015, this month's graduate shows will be a last chance to display their hard-earned skills and natural talent before being exposed to the cut-throat performing arts world that exists outside the walls of the prestigious school.
Come graduation day they officially become NIDA alumni, a celebrated club that includes Cate Blanchett, Catherine Martin, Hugo Weaving and Baz Luhrmann, and there are surely more than a few hoping to join their rank of international success.
"There's certainly added pressure and expectation when people find out you studied at NIDA because they immediately think you must be great, but that also opens doors that otherwise wouldn't," third-year acting student Maree Cole says. "When I first applied, I never thought I'd get in."
Graduates Maree Cole (actor). Soon-to-be NIDA graduates showcase their talents in new theatre production Stranger I Am - the story of a young woman Aimee, who goes on a journey of self-discovery following the death of her mother. Photo: Edwina Pickles 
Cole is busy with final rehearsals for Stranger I Am , a new theatre piece created by guest director Craig Ilott with original music from iOTA and Caitlin Park.
Advertisement She plays the lead role of Aimee, a young woman on a journey of self-discovery following the death of her mother.
The piece requires the cast to perform aerial stunts such as walking on walls, all taught as part of their studies at NIDA.
Graduates Maree Cole (actor) and Jonathan Hindmarsh (costume designer). Photo: Edwina Pickles 
"It's certainly not your regular everyday narrative, but it's been an amazing opportunity to perform new, original work which is something that as a student you don't usually get the chance to do," Cole says.
Third-year design for performance student Jonathan Hindmarsh is also graduating this year, and has created the play's costumes.
"I created two costumes for Aimee to represent the two different worlds she goes through – there's the external world which is full of clean, elegant lines, and the broken-down, internal world she goes into and that costume reflects the fragmentation of her mind," he says.
Although NIDA is widely recognised as the most prestigious performing arts school in Australia, the acting and performance design fields are notoriously difficult to break into, and both Cole and Hindmarsh remain cautious in their expectations for the future.
"From here, hopefully I'll get an agent, build contacts and keep myself busy – the good thing about NIDA is that it's prepared us to create our own work because it can be so hard to find work in this industry," Cole says.
Hindmarsh says while being a NIDA graduate is something he'll always treasure, it's only the first stepping stone of many in what he hopes will be a successful career.
"I don't think being a NIDA graduate is anything I can coast on – it's now up to me to get out there and actually prove that I have what it takes to be an interesting and challenging designer," he says.
Stranger I Am  runs from October 16-23. To book tickets, visit nida.edu.au/student-productions
